myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:program which contains a notice placed by the copyright holder or
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:other authorized party saying it may be distributed under the terms of
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:this Lesser General Public License (also called "this License").
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Each licensee is addressed as "you".
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  A "library" means a collection of software functions and/or data
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:prepared so as to be conveniently linked with application programs
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:(which use some of those functions and data) to form executables.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  The "Library", below, refers to any such software library or work
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:which has been distributed under these terms.  A "work based on the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Library" means either the Library or any derivative work under
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:copyright law: that is to say, a work containing the Library or a
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:portion of it, either verbatim or with modifications and/or translated
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:straightforwardly into another language.  (Hereinafter, translation is
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:included without limitation in the term "modification".)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  "Source code" for a work means the preferred form of the work for
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:making modifications to it.  For a library, complete source code means
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:all the source code for all modules it contains, plus any associated
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:interface definition files, plus the scripts used to control compilation
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:and installation of the library.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  Activities other than copying, distribution and modification are not
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:covered by this License; they are outside its scope.  The act of
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:running a program using the Library is not restricted, and output from
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:such a program is covered only if its contents constitute a work based
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:on the Library (independent of the use of the Library in a tool for
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:writing it).  Whether that is true depends on what the Library does
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:and what the program that uses the Library does.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  1. You may copy and distribute verbatim copies of the Library's
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:complete source code as you receive it, in any medium, provided that
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:you conspicuously and appropriately publish on each copy an
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:appropriate copyright notice and disclaimer of warranty; keep intact
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:all the notices that refer to this License and to the absence of any
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:warranty; and distribute a copy of this License along with the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Library.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  You may charge a fee for the physical act of transferring a copy,
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:and you may at your option offer warranty protection in exchange for a
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:fee.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  2. You may modify your copy or copies of the Library or any portion
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:of it, thus forming a work based on the Library, and copy and
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:distribute such modifications or work under the terms of Section 1
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:above, provided that you also meet all of these conditions:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    a) The modified work must itself be a software library.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    b) You must cause the files modified to carry prominent notices
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    stating that you changed the files and the date of any change.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    c) You must cause the whole of the work to be licensed at no
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    charge to all third parties under the terms of this License.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    d) If a facility in the modified Library refers to a function or a
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    table of data to be supplied by an application program that uses
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    the facility, other than as an argument passed when the facility
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    is invoked, then you must make a good faith effort to ensure that,
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    in the event an application does not supply such function or
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    table, the facility still operates, and performs whatever part of
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    its purpose remains meaningful.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    (For example, a function in a library to compute square roots has
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    a purpose that is entirely well-defined independent of the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    application.  Therefore, Subsection 2d requires that any
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    application-supplied function or table used by this function must
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    be optional: if the application does not supply it, the square
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    root function must still compute square roots.)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:These requirements apply to the modified work as a whole.  If
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:identifiable sections of that work are not derived from the Library,
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:and can be reasonably considered independent and separate works in
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:themselves, then this License, and its terms, do not apply to those
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:sections when you distribute them as separate works.  But when you
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:distribute the same sections as part of a whole which is a work based
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:on the Library, the distribution of the whole must be on the terms of
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:this License, whose permissions for other licensees extend to the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:entire whole, and thus to each and every part regardless of who wrote
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:it.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Thus, it is not the intent of this section to claim rights or contest
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:your rights to work written entirely by you; rather, the intent is to
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:exercise the right to control the distribution of derivative or
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:collective works based on the Library.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:In addition, mere aggregation of another work not based on the Library
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:with the Library (or with a work based on the Library) on a volume of
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:a storage or distribution medium does not bring the other work under
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:the scope of this License.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  3. You may opt to apply the terms of the ordinary GNU General Public
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:License instead of this License to a given copy of the Library.  To do
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:this, you must alter all the notices that refer to this License, so
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:that they refer to the ordinary GNU General Public License, version 2,
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:instead of to this License.  (If a newer version than version 2 of the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:ordinary GNU General Public License has appeared, then you can specify
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:that version instead if you wish.)  Do not make any other change in
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:these notices.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  Once this change is made in a given copy, it is irreversible for
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:that copy, so the ordinary GNU General Public License applies to all
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:subsequent copies and derivative works made from that copy.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  This option is useful when you wish to copy part of the code of
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:the Library into a program that is not a library.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  4. You may copy and distribute the Library (or a portion or
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:derivative of it, under Section 2) in object code or executable form
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:under the terms of Sections 1 and 2 above provided that you accompany
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:it with the complete corresponding machine-readable source code, which
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:must be distributed under the terms of Sections 1 and 2 above on a
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:medium customarily used for software interchange.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  If distribution of object code is made by offering access to copy
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:from a designated place, then offering equivalent access to copy the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:source code from the same place satisfies the requirement to
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:distribute the source code, even though third parties are not
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:compelled to copy the source along with the object code.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  5. A program that contains no derivative of any portion of the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Library, but is designed to work with the Library by being compiled or
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:linked with it, is called a "work that uses the Library".  Such a
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:work, in isolation, is not a derivative work of the Library, and
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:therefore falls outside the scope of this License.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  However, linking a "work that uses the Library" with the Library
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:creates an executable that is a derivative of the Library (because it
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:contains portions of the Library), rather than a "work that uses the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:library".  The executable is therefore covered by this License.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Section 6 states terms for distribution of such executables.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  When a "work that uses the Library" uses material from a header file
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:that is part of the Library, the object code for the work may be a
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:derivative work of the Library even though the source code is not.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Whether this is true is especially significant if the work can be
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:linked without the Library, or if the work is itself a library.  The
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:threshold for this to be true is not precisely defined by law.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  If such an object file uses only numerical parameters, data
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:structure layouts and accessors, and small macros and small inline
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:functions (ten lines or less in length), then the use of the object
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:file is unrestricted, regardless of whether it is legally a derivative
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:work.  (Executables containing this object code plus portions of the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Library will still fall under Section 6.)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  Otherwise, if the work is a derivative of the Library, you may
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:distribute the object code for the work under the terms of Section 6.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Any executables containing that work also fall under Section 6,
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:whether or not they are linked directly with the Library itself.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  6. As an exception to the Sections above, you may also combine or
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:link a "work that uses the Library" with the Library to produce a
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:work containing portions of the Library, and distribute that work
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:under terms of your choice, provided that the terms permit
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:modification of the work for the customer's own use and reverse
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:engineering for debugging such modifications.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  You must give prominent notice with each copy of the work that the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Library is used in it and that the Library and its use are covered by
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:this License.  You must supply a copy of this License.  If the work
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:during execution displays copyright notices, you must include the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:copyright notice for the Library among them, as well as a reference
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:directing the user to the copy of this License.  Also, you must do one
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:of these things:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    a) Accompany the work with the complete corresponding
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    machine-readable source code for the Library including whatever
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    changes were used in the work (which must be distributed under
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    Sections 1 and 2 above); and, if the work is an executable linked
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    with the Library, with the complete machine-readable "work that
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    uses the Library", as object code and/or source code, so that the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    user can modify the Library and then relink to produce a modified
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    executable containing the modified Library.  (It is understood
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    that the user who changes the contents of definitions files in the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    Library will not necessarily be able to recompile the application
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    to use the modified definitions.)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    b) Use a suitable shared library mechanism for linking with the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    Library.  A suitable mechanism is one that (1) uses at run time a
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    copy of the library already present on the user's computer system,
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    rather than copying library functions into the executable, and (2)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    will operate properly with a modified version of the library, if
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    the user installs one, as long as the modified version is
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    interface-compatible with the version that the work was made with.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    c) Accompany the work with a written offer, valid for at
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    least three years, to give the same user the materials
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    specified in Subsection 6a, above, for a charge no more
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    than the cost of performing this distribution.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    d) If distribution of the work is made by offering access to copy
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    from a designated place, offer equivalent access to copy the above
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    specified materials from the same place.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    e) Verify that the user has already received a copy of these
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:    materials or that you have already sent this user a copy.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:  For an executable, the required form of the "work that uses the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:Library" must include any data and utility programs needed for
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:reproducing the executable from it.  However, as a special exception,
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:the materials to be distributed need not include anything that is
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:normally distributed (in either source or binary form) with the major
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:components (compiler, kernel, and so on) of the operating system on
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:which the executable runs, unless that component itself accompanies
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:the executable.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/LICENSE:

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:<?php
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:// example on using PHPMailer with GMAIL
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:include("class.phpmailer.php");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:include("class.smtp.php"); // note, this is optional - gets called from main class if not already loaded
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail             = new PHPMailer();
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$body             = $mail->getFile('contents.html');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$body             = eregi_replace("[\]",'',$body);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->IsSMTP();
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->SMTPAuth   = true;                  // enable SMTP authentication
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->SMTPSecure = "ssl";                 // sets the prefix to the servier
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->Host       = "smtp.gmail.com";      // sets GMAIL as the SMTP server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->Port       = 465;                   // set the SMTP port
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->Username   = "yourname@gmail.com";  // GMAIL username
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->Password   = "password";            // GMAIL password
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->From       = "replyto@yourdomain.com";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->FromName   = "Webmaster";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->Subject    = "This is the subject";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->AltBody    = "This is the body when user views in plain text format"; //Text Body
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->WordWrap   = 50; // set word wrap
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->MsgHTML($body);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->AddReplyTo("replyto@yourdomain.com","Webmaster");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->AddAttachment("/path/to/file.zip");             // attachment
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->AddAttachment("/path/to/image.jpg", "new.jpg"); // attachment
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->AddAddress("username@domain.com","First Last");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:$mail->IsHTML(true); // send as HTML
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:if(!$mail->Send()) {
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:  echo "Mailer Error: " . $mail->ErrorInfo;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:} else {
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:  echo "Message has been sent";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:}
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/use_gmail.txt:?>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<html>

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<h2>Examples using phpmailer</h2>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<h3>1. Advanced Example</h3>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<p>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:This demonstrates sending out multiple email messages with binary attachments
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:from a MySQL database with multipart/alternative support.<p>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<table cellpadding="4" border="1" width="80%">
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<tr>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<td bgcolor="#CCCCCC">
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<pre>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:require("class.phpmailer.php");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$mail = new phpmailer();
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$mail->From     = "list@example.com";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$mail->FromName = "List manager";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$mail->Host     = "smtp1.example.com;smtp2.example.com";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$mail->Mailer   = "smtp";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:@MYSQL_CONNECT("localhost","root","password");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:@mysql_select_db("my_company");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$query  = "SELECT full_name, email, photo FROM employee WHERE id=$id";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$result = @MYSQL_QUERY($query);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:while ($row = mysql_fetch_array ($result))
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:{
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    // HTML body
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $body  = "Hello &lt;font size=\"4\"&gt;" . $row["full_name"] . "&lt;/font&gt;, &lt;p&gt;";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $body .= "&lt;i&gt;Your&lt;/i&gt; personal photograph to this message.&lt;p&gt;";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $body .= "Sincerely, &lt;br&gt;";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $body .= "phpmailer List manager";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    // Plain text body (for mail clients that cannot read HTML)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $text_body  = "Hello " . $row["full_name"] . ", \n\n";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $text_body .= "Your personal photograph to this message.\n\n";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $text_body .= "Sincerely, \n";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $text_body .= "phpmailer List manager";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $mail->Body    = $body;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $mail->AltBody = $text_body;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $mail->AddAddress($row["email"], $row["full_name"]);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $mail->AddStringAttachment($row["photo"], "YourPhoto.jpg");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    if(!$mail->Send())
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:        echo "There has been a mail error sending to " . $row["email"] . "&lt;br&gt;";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    // Clear all addresses and attachments for next loop
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $mail->ClearAddresses();
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    $mail->ClearAttachments();
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:}
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</pre>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</td>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</tr>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</table>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<p>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<h3>2. Extending phpmailer</h3>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<p>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:Extending classes with inheritance is one of the most
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:powerful features of object-oriented
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:programming.  It allows you to make changes to the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:original class for your
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:own personal use without hacking the original
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:classes.  Plus, it is very
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:easy to do. I've provided an example:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<p>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:Here's a class that extends the phpmailer class and sets the defaults
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:for the particular site:<br>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:PHP include file: <b>mail.inc.php</b>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<p>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<table cellpadding="4" border="1" width="80%">
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<tr>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<td bgcolor="#CCCCCC">
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<pre>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:require("class.phpmailer.php");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:class my_phpmailer extends phpmailer {
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    // Set default variables for all new objects
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    var $From     = "from@example.com";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    var $FromName = "Mailer";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    var $Host     = "smtp1.example.com;smtp2.example.com";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    var $Mailer   = "smtp";                         // Alternative to IsSMTP()
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    var $WordWrap = 75;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    // Replace the default error_handler
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    function error_handler($msg) {
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:        print("My Site Error");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:        print("Description:");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:        printf("%s", $msg);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:        exit;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    }
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    // Create an additional function
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    function do_something($something) {
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:        // Place your new code here
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:    }
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:}
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</td>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</tr>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</table>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<br>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:Now here's a normal PHP page in the site, which will have all the defaults set
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:above:<br>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:Normal PHP file: <b>mail_test.php</b>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<p>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<table cellpadding="4" border="1" width="80%">
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<tr>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<td bgcolor="#CCCCCC">
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:<pre>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:require("mail.inc.php");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:// Instantiate your new class
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$mail = new my_phpmailer;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:// Now you only need to add the necessary stuff
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$mail->AddAddress("josh@example.com", "Josh Adams");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$mail->Subject = "Here is the subject";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$mail->Body    = "This is the message body";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:$mail->AddAttachment("c:/temp/11-10-00.zip", "new_name.zip");  // optional name
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:if(!$mail->Send())
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:{
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:   echo "There was an error sending the message";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:   exit;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:}
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:echo "Message was sent successfully";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</pre>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</td>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</tr>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</table>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</p>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</body>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/extending.html:</html>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:NEW CALLBACK FUNCTION:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:======================
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:We have had requests for a method to process the results of sending emails 
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:through PHPMailer. In this new release, we have implemented a callback
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:function that passes the results of each email sent (to, cc, and/or bcc). 
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:We have provided an example that echos the results back to the screen. The
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:callback function can be used for any purpose. With minor modifications, the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:callback function can be used to create CSV logs, post results to databases,
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:etc.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:Please review the test.php script for the example.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:It's pretty straight forward.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:Enjoy!
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Callback_function_notes.txt:Andy
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:This is built for PHP Mailer 1.72 and was not tested with any previous version. It was developed under PHP 4.3.11 (E_ALL). It works under PHP 5 and 5.1 with E_ALL, but not in Strict mode due to var deprecation (but then neither does PHP Mailer either!). It follows the RFC 1939 standard explicitly and is fully commented.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:With that noted, here is how to implement it:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:Install the class file
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:I didn't want to modify the PHP Mailer classes at all, so you will have to include/require this class along with the base one. It can sit quite happily in the phpmailer-1.72 directory:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:[geshi lang=php] require 'phpmailer-1.72/class.phpmailer.php'; require 'phpmailer-1.72/class.pop3.php'; [/geshi]
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:When you need it, create your POP3 object
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:Right before I invoke PHP Mailer I activate the POP3 authorisation. POP3 before SMTP is a process whereby you login to your web hosts POP3 mail server BEFORE sending out any emails via SMTP. The POP3 logon 'verifies' your ability to send email by SMTP, which typically otherwise blocks you. On my web host (Pair Networks) a single POP3 logon is enough to 'verify' you for 90 minutes. Here is some sample PHP code that activates the POP3 logon and then sends an email via PHP Mailer:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:[geshi lang=php] Authorise('pop3.example.com', 110, 30, 'mailer', 'password', 1); $mail = new PHPMailer(); $mail->SMTPDebug = 2; $mail->IsSMTP(); $mail->IsHTML(false); $mail->Host = 'relay.example.com'; $mail->From = 'mailer@example.com'; $mail->FromName = 'Example Mailer'; $mail->Subject = 'My subject'; $mail->Body = 'Hello world'; $mail->AddAddress('rich@corephp.co.uk', 'Richard Davey'); if (!$mail->Send()) { echo $mail->ErrorInfo; } ?> [/geshi]
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:The PHP Mailer parts of this code should be obvious to anyone who has used PHP Mailer before. One thing to note - you almost certainly will not need to use SMTP Authentication *and* POP3 before SMTP together. The Authorisation method is a proxy method to all of the others within that class. There are Connect, Logon and Disconnect methods available, but I wrapped them in the single Authorisation one to make things easier.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:The Parameters
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:The Authorise parameters are as follows:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:[geshi lang=php]$pop->Authorise('pop3.example.com', 110, 30, 'mailer', 'password', 1);[/geshi]
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:   1. pop3.example.com - The POP3 Mail Server Name (hostname or IP address)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:   2. 110 - The POP3 Port on which to connect (default is usually 110, but check with your host)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:   3. 30 - A connection time-out value (in seconds)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:   4. mailer - The POP3 Username required to logon
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:   5. password - The POP3 Password required to logon
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:   6. 1 - The class debug level (0 = off, 1+ = debug output is echoed to the browser)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:Final Comments + the Download
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:1) This class does not support APOP connections. This is only because I did not have an APOP server to test with, but if you'd like to see that added just contact me.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:2) Opening and closing lots of POP3 connections can be quite a resource/network drain. If you need to send a whole batch of emails then just perform the authentication once at the start, and then loop through your mail sending script. Providing this process doesn't take longer than the verification period lasts on your POP3 server, you should be fine. With my host that period is 90 minutes, i.e. plenty of time.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:3) If you have heavy requirements for this script (i.e. send a LOT of email on a frequent basis) then I would advise seeking out an alternative sending method (direct SMTP ideally). If this isn't possible then you could modify this class so the 'last authorised' date is recorded somewhere (MySQL, Flat file, etc) meaning you only open a new connection if the old one has expired, saving you precious overhead.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:4) There are lots of other POP3 classes for PHP available. However most of them implement the full POP3 command set, where-as this one is purely for authentication, and much lighter as a result. However using any of the other POP3 classes to just logon to your server would have the same net result. At the end of the day, use whatever method you feel most comfortable with.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:Download
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:Here is the full class file plus my test script: POP_before_SMTP_PHPMailer.zip (4 KB) - Please note that it does not include PHPMailer itself.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/pop3_article.txt:My thanks to Chris Ryan for the inspiration (even if indirectly, via his SMTP class)

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:</head>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:<center>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:<div class="width">
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:<h2>PHPMailer FAQ</h2>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:<ul>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  <li><b style="background-color: #FFFF00">Q:</b> <b>I&#039;m using the SMTP mailer and I keep on getting a timeout message
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  well before the X seconds I set it for.  What gives?</b><br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  <b style="background-color: #FFFF00">A:</b> PHP versions 4.0.4pl1 and earlier have a bug in which sockets timeout
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  early.  You can fix this by re-compiling PHP 4.0.4pl1 with this fix:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  <a href="timeoutfix.diff">timeoutfix.diff</a>. Otherwise you can wait for the new PHP release.<br /><br /></li>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  <li><b style="background-color: #FFFF00">Q:</b> <b>I am concerned that using include files will take up too much
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  processing time on my computer.  How can I make it run faster?</b><br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  <b style="background-color: #FFFF00">A:</b>  PHP by itself is very fast.  Much faster than ASP or JSP running on
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  the same type of server.  This is because it has very little overhead compared
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  to its competitors and it pre-compiles all of
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  its code before it runs each script (in PHP4).  However, all of
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  this compiling and re-compiling can take up a lot of valuable
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  computer resources.  However, there are programs out there that compile
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  PHP code and store it in memory (or on mmaped files) to reduce the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  processing immensely.  Two of these: <a href="http://apc.communityconnect.com">APC
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  (Alternative PHP Cache)</a> and <a href="http://bwcache.bware.it/index.htm">Afterburner</a>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  (<a href="http://www.mm4.de/php4win/mod_php4_win32/">Win32 download</a>)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  are excellent free tools that do just this.  If you have the money
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  you might also try <a href="http://www.zend.com">Zend Cache</a>, it is
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  even faster than the open source varieties.  All of these tools make your
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  scripts run faster while also reducing the load on your server. I have tried
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  them myself and they are quite stable too.<br /><br /></li>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  <li><b style="background-color: #FFFF00">Q:</b> <b>What mailer gives me the best performance?</b><br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  <b style="background-color: #FFFF00">A:</b> On a single machine the <b>sendmail (or Qmail)</b> is fastest overall.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  Next fastest is mail() to give you the best performance. Both do not have the overhead of SMTP.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  If you have you have your mail server on a another machine then
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  SMTP is your only option, but you do get the benefit of redundant mail servers.<br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  If you are running a mailing list with thousands of names, the fastest mailers in order are: SMTP, sendmail (or Qmail), mail().<br /><br /></li>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  <li><b style="background-color: #FFFF00">Q:</b> <b>When I try to attach a file with on my server I get a
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  "Could not find {file} on filesystem error".  Why is this?</b><br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  <b style="background-color: #FFFF00">A:</b> If you are using a Unix machine this is probably because the user
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  running your web server does not have read access to the directory in question.  If you are using Windows,
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  then the problem probably is that you have used single backslashes to denote directories (\).
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  A single backslash has a special meaning to PHP so these are not
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  valid.  Instead use double backslashes ("\\") or a single forward
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:  slash ("/").<br /><br /></li>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:</ul>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:</div>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:</center>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:</body>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/faq.html:</html>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:CREATE DKIM KEYS and DNS Resource Record:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:=========================================
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:To create DomainKeys Identified Mail keys, visit:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:http://dkim.worxware.com/
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:... read the information, fill in the form, and download the ZIP file 
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:containing the public key, private key, DNS Resource Record and instructions
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:to add to your DNS Zone Record, and the PHPMailer code to enable DKIM
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:digital signing.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:/*** PROTECT YOUR PRIVATE & PUBLIC KEYS ***/
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:You need to protect your DKIM private and public keys from being viewed or
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:accessed. Add protection to your .htaccess file as in this example:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:# secure htkeyprivate file
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:<Files .htkeyprivate>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:  order allow,deny
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:  deny from all
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:</Files>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:# secure htkeypublic file
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:<Files .htkeypublic>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:  order allow,deny
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:  deny from all
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:</Files>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:(the actual .htaccess additions are in the ZIP file sent back to you from 
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:http://dkim.worxware.com/ 
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:A few notes on using DomainKey Identified Mail (DKIM):
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:You do not need to use PHPMailer to DKIM sign  emails IF:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:- you enable DomainKey support and add the DNS resource record
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:- you use your outbound mail server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:If you are a third-party emailer that works on behalf of domain owners to
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:send their emails from your own server:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:- you absolutely have to DKIM sign outbound emails
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:- the domain owner has to add the DNS resource record to match the 
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:  private key, public key, selector, identity, and domain that you create
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:- use caution with the "selector" ... at least one "selector" will already
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:  exist in the DNS Zone Record of the domain at the domain owner's server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:  you need to ensure that the "selector" you use is unique
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:Note: since the IP address will not match the domain owner's DNS Zone record
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:you can be certain that email providers that validate based on DomainKey will
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:check the domain owner's DNS Zone record for your DNS resource record. Before
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:sending out emails on behalf of domain owners, ensure they have entered the 
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:DNS resource record you provided them.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:Enjoy!
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:Andy
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:PS. if you need additional information about DKIM, please see:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/DomainKeys_notes.txt:http://www.dkim.org/info/dkim-faq.html
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:If you are having problems connecting or sending emails through your SMTP server, please note:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:1. The new rewrite of class.smtp.php provides more information about the processing/errors taking place
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:2. Use the debug functionality of class.smtp.php. To do that, in your own script add the debug level you wish to use. An example of that is:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:$mail->SMTPDebug = 1;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:$mail->IsSMTP();  // telling the class to use SMTP
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:$mail->SMTPAuth   = true;                // enable SMTP authentication
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:$mail->Port       = 26;                  // set the SMTP port
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:$mail->Host       = "mail.yourhost.com"; // SMTP server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:$mail->Username   = "name@yourhost.com"; // SMTP account username
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:$mail->Password   = "your password";     // SMTP account password
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:Notes on this:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:$mail->SMTPDebug = 0; ... will disable debugging (you can also leave this out completely, 0 is the default
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:$mail->SMTPDebug = 1; ... will echo errors and messages
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:$mail->SMTPDebug = 2; ... will echo messages only
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:... and finally, the options are 0, 1, and 2 ... any number greater than 2 will be interpreted as 2
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:And finally, don't forget to disable debugging before going into production.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:Enjoy!
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/docs/Note_for_SMTP_debugging.txt:Andy
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:/*******************************************************************
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:* The http://phpmailer.codeworxtech.com/ website now carries a few *
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:* advertisements through the Google Adsense network. Please visit  *
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:* the advertiser sites and help us offset some of our costs.       *
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:* Thanks ....                                                      *
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:********************************************************************/
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:PHPMailer
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Full Featured Email Transfer Class for PHP
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:==========================================
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Version 5.0.0 (April 02, 2009)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:With the release of this version, we are initiating a new version numbering
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:system to differentiate from the PHP4 version of PHPMailer.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Most notable in this release is fully object oriented code.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:We now have available the PHPDocumentor (phpdocs) documentation. This is
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:separate from the regular download to keep file sizes down. Please see the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:download area of http://phpmailer.codeworxtech.com.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:We also have created a new test script (see /test_script) that you can use
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:right out of the box. Copy the /test_script folder directly to your server (in
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:the same structure ... with class.phpmailer.php and class.smtp.php in the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:folder above it. Then launch the test script with:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:http://www.yourdomain.com/phpmailer/test_script/index.php
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:from this one script, you can test your server settings for mail(), sendmail (or
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:qmail), and SMTP. This will email you a sample email (using contents.html for
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:the email body) and two attachments. One of the attachments is used as an inline
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:image to demonstrate how PHPMailer will automatically detect if attachments are
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:the same source as inline graphics and only include one version. Once you click
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:the Submit button, the results will be displayed including any SMTP debug
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:information and send status. We will also display a version of the script that
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:you can cut and paste to include in your projects. Enjoy!
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Version 2.3 (November 08, 2008)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:We have removed the /phpdoc from the downloads. All documentation is now on
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:the http://phpmailer.codeworxtech.com website.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:The phpunit.php has been updated to support PHP5.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:For all other changes and notes, please see the changelog.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Version 2.2 (July 15 2008)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- see the changelog.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Version 2.1 (June 04 2008)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:With this release, we are announcing that the development of PHPMailer for PHP5
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:will be our focus from this date on. We have implemented all the enhancements
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:and fixes from the latest release of PHPMailer for PHP4.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Far more important, though, is that this release of PHPMailer (v2.1) is
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:fully tested with E_STRICT error checking enabled.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:** NOTE: WE HAVE A NEW LANGUAGE VARIABLE FOR DIGITALLY SIGNED S/MIME EMAILS.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:   IF YOU CAN HELP WITH LANGUAGES OTHER THAN ENGLISH AND SPANISH, IT WOULD BE
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:   APPRECIATED.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:We have now added S/MIME functionality (ability to digitally sign emails).
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:BIG THANKS TO "sergiocambra" for posting this patch back in November 2007.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:The "Signed Emails" functionality adds the Sign method to pass the private key
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:filename and the password to read it, and then email will be sent with
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:content-type multipart/signed and with the digital signature attached.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:A quick note on E_STRICT:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- In about half the test environments the development version was subjected
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:  to, an error was thrown for the date() functions (used at line 1565 and 1569).
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:  This is NOT a PHPMailer error, it is the result of an incorrectly configured
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:  PHP5 installation. The fix is to modify your 'php.ini' file and include the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:  date.timezone = America/New York
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:  directive, (for your own server timezone)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- If you do get this error, and are unable to access your php.ini file, there is
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:  a workaround. In your PHP script, add
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:  date_default_timezone_set('America/Toronto');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:  * do NOT try to use
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:  $myVar = date_default_timezone_get();
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:  as a test, it will throw an error.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:We have also included more example files to show the use of "sendmail", "mail()",
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:"smtp", and "gmail".
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:We are also looking for more programmers to join the volunteer development team.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:If you have an interest in this, please let us know.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Enjoy!
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Version 2.1.0beta1 & beta2
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:please note, this is BETA software
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:** DO NOT USE THIS IN PRODUCTION OR LIVE PROJECTS
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:INTENDED STRICTLY FOR TESTING
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:** NOTE:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:As of November 2007, PHPMailer has a new project team headed by industry
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:veteran Andy Prevost (codeworxtech). The first release in more than two
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:years will focus on fixes, adding ease-of-use enhancements, provide
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:basic compatibility with PHP4 and PHP5 using PHP5 backwards compatibility
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:features. A new release is planned before year-end 2007 that will provide
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:full compatiblity with PHP4 and PHP5, as well as more bug fixes.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:We are looking for project developers to assist in restoring PHPMailer to
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:its leadership position. Our goals are to simplify use of PHPMailer, provide
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:good documentation and examples, and retain backward compatibility to level
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:1.7.3 standards.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:If you are interested in helping out, visit http://sourceforge.net/projects/phpmailer
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:and indicate your interest.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:**
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:http://phpmailer.sourceforge.net/

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:software availability and distribution.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Class Features:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- Send emails with multiple TOs, CCs, BCCs and REPLY-TOs
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- Redundant SMTP servers
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- Multipart/alternative emails for mail clients that do not read HTML email
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- Support for 8bit, base64, binary, and quoted-printable encoding
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- Uses the same methods as the very popular AspEmail active server (COM) component
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- SMTP authentication
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- Native language support
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:- Word wrap, and more!
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Why you might need it:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Many PHP developers utilize email in their code.  The only PHP function
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:that supports this is the mail() function.  However, it does not expose
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:any of the popular features that many email clients use nowadays like
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:HTML-based emails and attachments. There are two proprietary
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:development tools out there that have all the functionality built into
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:easy to use classes: AspEmail(tm) and AspMail.  Both of these
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:programs are COM components only available on Windows.  They are also a
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:little pricey for smaller projects.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Since I do Linux development Iï¿½ve missed these tools for my PHP coding.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:So I built a version myself that implements the same methods (object
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:calls) that the Windows-based components do. It is open source and the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:LGPL license allows you to place the class in your proprietary PHP
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:projects.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Installation:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:Copy class.phpmailer.php into your php.ini include_path. If you are
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:using the SMTP mailer then place class.smtp.php in your path as well.
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:In the language directory you will find several files like
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:phpmailer.lang-en.php.  If you look right before the .php extension
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:that there are two letters.  These represent the language type of the
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:translation file.  For instance "en" is the English file and "br" is
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:the Portuguese file.  Chose the file that best fits with your language
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:and place it in the PHP include path.  If your language is English
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:then you have nothing more to do.  If it is a different language then
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:you must point PHPMailer to the correct translation.  To do this, call
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:the PHPMailer SetLanguage method like so:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:// To load the Portuguese version
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->SetLanguage("br", "/optional/path/to/language/directory/");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:That's it.  You should now be ready to use PHPMailer!
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:A Simple Example:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:<?php
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:require("class.phpmailer.php");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail = new PHPMailer();
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->IsSMTP();                                      // set mailer to use SMTP
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->Host = "smtp1.example.com;smtp2.example.com";  // specify main and backup server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->SMTPAuth = true;     // turn on SMTP authentication
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->Username = "jswan";  // SMTP username
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->Password = "secret"; // SMTP password
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->From = "from@example.com";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->FromName = "Mailer";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->AddAddress("josh@example.net", "Josh Adams");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->AddAddress("ellen@example.com");                  // name is optional
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->AddReplyTo("info@example.com", "Information");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->WordWrap = 50;                                 // set word wrap to 50 characters
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->AddAttachment("/var/tmp/file.tar.gz");         // add attachments
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->AddAttachment("/tmp/image.jpg", "new.jpg");    // optional name
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->IsHTML(true);                                  // set email format to HTML
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->Subject = "Here is the subject";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->Body    = "This is the HTML message body <b>in bold!</b>";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:$mail->AltBody = "This is the body in plain text for non-HTML mail clients";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:if(!$mail->Send())
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:{
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:   echo "Message could not be sent. <p>";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:   echo "Mailer Error: " . $mail->ErrorInfo;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:   exit;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:}
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:echo "Message has been sent";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:?>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/README:CHANGELOG

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:<br>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:&nbsp;This is a test of PHPMailer.<br>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:<br>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:This particular example uses <strong>HTML</strong>, with a &lt;div&gt; tag and inline<br>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:styles.<br>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:<br>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:Also note the use of the PHPMailer logo above with no specific code to handle
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:including it.<br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:Included are two attachments:<br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:phpmailer.gif is an attachment and used inline as a graphic (above)<br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:phpmailer_mini.gif is an attachment<br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:<br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:PHPMailer:<br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:Author: Andy Prevost (codeworxtech@users.sourceforge.net)<br />
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/contents.html:Author: Marcus Bointon (coolbru@users.sourceforge.net)<br />

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:<title>PHPMailer - SMTP basic test with no authentication</title>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:</head>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:<body>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:<?php
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php://error_reporting(E_ALL);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:error_reporting(E_STRICT);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:date_default_timezone_set('America/Toronto');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:require_once('../class.phpmailer.php');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php://include("class.smtp.php"); // optional, gets called from within class.phpmailer.php if not already loaded
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail             = new PHPMailer();
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$body             = file_get_contents('contents.html');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$body             = eregi_replace("[\]",'',$body);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->IsSMTP(); // telling the class to use SMTP
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->Host       = "mail.yourdomain.com"; // SMTP server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->SMTPDebug  = 2;                     // enables SMTP debug information (for testing)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:                                           // 1 = errors and messages
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:                                           // 2 = messages only
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->SetFrom('name@yourdomain.com', 'First Last');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->AddReplyTo("name@yourdomain.com","First Last");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->Subject    = "PHPMailer Test Subject via smtp, basic with no authentication";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->AltBody    = "To view the message, please use an HTML compatible email viewer!"; // optional, comment out and test
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->MsgHTML($body);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$address = "whoto@otherdomain.com";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->AddAddress($address, "John Doe");
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->AddAttachment("images/phpmailer.gif");      // attachment
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:$mail->AddAttachment("images/phpmailer_mini.gif"); // attachment
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:if(!$mail->Send()) {
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:  echo "Mailer Error: " . $mail->ErrorInfo;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:} else {
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:  echo "Message sent!";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic_no_auth.php:}

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:</head>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:<body>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:<?php
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php://error_reporting(E_ALL);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:error_reporting(E_STRICT);

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:date_default_timezone_set('America/Toronto');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:require_once('../class.phpmailer.php');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php://include("class.smtp.php"); // optional, gets called from within class.phpmailer.php if not already loaded
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail             = new PHPMailer();
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$body             = file_get_contents('contents.html');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$body             = eregi_replace("[\]",'',$body);
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail->IsSMTP(); // telling the class to use SMTP
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail->Host       = "mail.yourdomain.com"; // SMTP server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail->SMTPDebug  = 2;                     // enables SMTP debug information (for testing)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:                                           // 1 = errors and messages
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:                                           // 2 = messages only
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail->SMTPAuth   = true;                  // enable SMTP authentication
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail->Host       = "mail.yourdomain.com"; // sets the SMTP server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail->Port       = 26;                    // set the SMTP port for the GMAIL server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail->Username   = "yourname@yourdomain"; // SMTP account username
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail->Password   = "yourpassword";        // SMTP account password
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail->SetFrom('name@yourdomain.com', 'First Last');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:$mail->AddReplyTo("name@yourdomain.com","First Last");

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:  echo "Mailer Error: " . $mail->ErrorInfo;
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:} else {
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_basic.php:  echo "Message sent!";

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:<html>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:<head>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:<title>PHPMailer - SMTP (Gmail) advanced test</title>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:</head>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:<body>
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:<?php
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:require_once('../class.phpmailer.php');
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php://include("class.smtp.php"); // optional, gets called from within class.phpmailer.php if not already loaded
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:$mail = new PHPMailer(true); // the true param means it will throw exceptions on errors, which we need to catch
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:$mail->IsSMTP(); // telling the class to use SMTP
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:try {
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->Host       = "mail.yourdomain.com"; // SMTP server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->SMTPDebug  = 2;                     // enables SMTP debug information (for testing)
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->SMTPAuth   = true;                  // enable SMTP authentication
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->SMTPSecure = "ssl";                 // sets the prefix to the servier
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->Host       = "smtp.gmail.com";      // sets GMAIL as the SMTP server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->Port       = 465;                   // set the SMTP port for the GMAIL server
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->Username   = "yourusername@gmail.com";  // GMAIL username
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->Password   = "yourpassword";            // GMAIL password

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->MsgHTML(file_get_contents('contents.html'));
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->AddAttachment('images/phpmailer.gif');      // attachment
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  $mail->AddAttachment('images/phpmailer_mini.gif'); // attachment

myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  echo "Message Sent OK</p>\n";
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:} catch (phpmailerException $e) {
myngl_myngl/PHPMailer/examples/test_smtp_gmail_advanced.php:  echo $e->errorMessage(); //Pretty error messages from PHPMailer
